At the age of 40, she is confident to borrow at the maximum limit. She uses the fund on the right purpose and it clearly improves her life. This time she wants to borrow $400 to buy rush to make sedge mats. Besides working, Mrs. C. also spends a lot of time taking care of her parents. She goes to class every other night and makes sedge mats with her parents during the others. Everyday her family makes 2 mats, each is sold at $3.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Quảng Khê là một xã nghèo nằm phía Nam huyện Quảng Xương, Thanh Hóa. Đời sống người dân nơi đây gặp nhiều khó khăn, các nguồn vốn không đến được với ngưòi nghèo họ thường phải vay nặng lãi. Năm 2003 Quỹ TYM đã về với địa phương và thực hiện phương thức cho vay vốn trả theo tuần. Gia đình chị Hà Thị Chân đã tham gia Quỹ từ ngày đó. Năm nay 40 tuổi, sức khỏe còn rất tốt nên các vòng vốn chị đều vay tối đa. Nguồn vốn được sử dụng đúng mục đích nên mang lại hiệu quả rõ rệt. Vòng vốn này chị vay 400 USD để mua thêm lác dự trữ cho việc làm chiếu Các chị cũng tích cực hỗ trợ bố mẹ rất nhiều. Một buổi đi học, một buổi cùng bố mẹ dệt chiếu. Mỗi ngày gia đình chị dệt được 2 đôi chiếu, một đôi bán được 3 USD.

loans.use: buy rush to make sedge mats

loans.name: Hoang Thi

texts.vi:
Ms Hoàng Thị L., 39 years old, became a member of micro funding 5 years ago. She had never missed her payments. The objective of the micro funding was to help build up the family finance. Ms L. is one of the members who always received maximum amount of loan in the village of Quảng Đức, district of Quảng Xương. This time she requests a loan of 450 USD to repair the tractor and to buy more ducks.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Hoàng Thị L., 39 tuổi, đã tham gia vào Quỹ từ 5 năm trước. Từ ngày tham gia Quỹ đến nay chưa lần nào cán bộ tín dụng phải nhắc nhở chị về việc hoàn trả. Cơ chế cho vay trả dần là điều kiện để gia đình anh chị phát triển kinh tế gia đình. Chị là một trong số những thành viên tại xã Quảng Đức, huyện Quảng Xương luôn vay vốn tối đa trong mỗi vòng vốn. Vòng vốn này chị đề nghị vay 450 USD về sử sang lại chiếc xe công nông dùng chuyên chở và mua thêm một số vịt để chăn nuôi.

loans.use: to repair her motor vehicle and buy ducks

loans.name: Le Thi

texts.vi:
Ms Lê Thị Vụ and her husband Lê Duy Hoàn live in Quảng Hùng, Quảng Xương, Thanh Hóa. They have 4 children. The living conditions are tough, they are having a hard time financially so the oldest of the children had quit school to go to work. The other three are still going to school. Mr Lê Duy Hoàn is a state employee working in a brick factory but work is not stable. They are requesting a loan of 400 USD to start a business of breeding pigs and chickens. They've already renovated the pigs pen. They have high hope to succeed in this venture.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer

Gia đình anh chị Lê Thị Vụ có 4 người con, hiện đang sống tại xã Quảng Hùng, Quảng Xương, Thanh Hóa. Điều kiện gia đình khó khăn nên cháu đầu phải nghỉ học đi làm trợ giúp bố mẹ. Hiện nay anh chị đang nuôi 3 cháu ăn học. Bản thân chồng chị, anh Lê Duy Hoàn, là cán bộ nhà máy gạch K2 nhưng vì công việc không nhiều nên không có việc làm ổn định. Với số vốn vay 400 USD anh chị định mua thêm lợn gà về chăn nuôi. Chuồng trại đã được anh chị sửa sang hoàn chỉnh hy vọng đợt chăn nuôi này sẽ đạt được kết quả cao hơn nữa.

loans.use: to buy chicken and pigs

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Ms Nguyễn Thị Hà lives in Quảng Xương with her husband and four children. Quảng Xương is in the district of Thanh Hóa, in the central region of Viet Nam. Ms Hà is 40 years old, she has over 20 years experience in sedge mat making. The profit from selling the sedge mats that she makes is good. But Ms Hà has a sense for business. Now she buys all the sedge mats from the other mats makers from her village then she would resell them in Sầm Sơn. On weekdays, she's able to buy 20 mats and on weekends, 150. Each sedge mat that she resells in Sầm Sơn, she makes a profit of 0.30 USD. She would need to have a considerable sum of money to buy enough sedge mats to meet the demand from the customers. She's requesting a loan of 600 USD. Ever since she starts the sedge mat retail business, her family financial is more solid.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer

Chị Nguyễn Thị Hà sống cùng chồng và 4 người con tại huyện Quảng Xương, Thanh Hóa, một tỉnh thuộc miền Trung Việt Nam. Năm nay 40 tuổi, chị đã có kinh nghiệm hơn 20 năm trong nghề làm chiếu. Thu nhập từ việc dệt chiếu mang lại cho chị Nguyễn Thị Hà những khoản thu đáng kể. Nhưng là một người có đầu óc kinh doanh, chị chuyển sang thu mua chiếu của các hộ gia đình trong thôn. Hàng ngày anh chi mua được 20 đôi chiếu, mỗi tuần được 150 đôi. Anh chị đưa hàng đi nhập ở Sầm Sơn mỗi đôi lãi được 0.3 USD. Cần phải có một số vốn lớn mới đủ cho hoạt động kinh doanh này, vòng vốn này chị đề nghị vay mức 600 USD.Từ khi chuyển sang kinh doanh chiếu kinh tế gia đình đã có những bước phát triển đáng kể.

loans.use: buy sedge mats to wholesale

loans.name: Trinh Thi

texts.vi:
Since the day that lives of people in Quang Hung village, Quang Xuong improved, they have been able to have savings and pay more attention to breakfast. Seeing this opportunity, Ms. Trinh Thi D. decided to open a breakfast restaurant. It’s been 10 years. Customers go to her restaurant not just because food there is cheap but also because she also offers good quality. If people come late, her food would be sold all out. Considering quality and profit equal, she confides: “That quality always comes first is the reason why our store is able to stay in business and develop like it is today. This time Ms. D. would like to borrow $400 to buy foodstuff, new table, chair, bowl, dishes for her restaurant. She also wants to buy some pigs to breed.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Kể từ ngày đời sống kinh tế xã Quảng Hùng, Quảng Xương phát triển hơn, người dân có của ăn của để, việc ăn sáng được người dân chú trọng, chị Trịnh Thị Đường đã quyết định mở quán ăn sáng để phục vụ các thượng đế. Từ đó đến nay cũng đã hơn 10 năm. Quán tiết canh, cháo lòng của gia đình anh chị luôn đông người không phải vì rẻ mà chất lượng luôn đảm bảo và hợp khẩu vị. Nếu đến muộn sẽ không còn. Không vì bán chạy hàng mà bỏ qua chất lượng, Chị tâm sự: Chất lượng đặt lên hàng đầu giá cả hợp lý nên chúng tôi mới tồn tại và phát triển như ngày hôm nay. Vòng vốn này gia đình anh chị đăng ký vay mức 400 USD để đầu tư vào mua hàng, sắm sửa bàn ghế bát đĩa đàng hoàng hơn. Ngoài ra còn đầu tư mua một số lợn con chăn nuôi thêm.

loans.use: buy foodstuff, new table, chair, bowl, dish

loans.name: Vien Thi

texts.vi:
Ms Viên Thị Dậu and her husband have four children. The youngest one is still attending school, the other three are working. Her husband works a moto-taxi driver in the city. Since her application for the fund the last time, Ms Dậu had received a lot of encouragement from her family. Her husband Trạnh is the one who's in charge of collecting money for the weekly repayments of the loan. After a few rounds of successful pigs breedings, Ms Dậu requests a loan of 500 USD to buy more pigs, chicken and to renovate the pig pen.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer

Gia đình chị Viên Thị Dậu có 4 ngưòi con, 3 cháu đã lớn và đã đi làm. Hiện còn một cháu đang đi học. Chồng chị làm nghề chạy xe ôm trên địa bàn huyện và thành phố, 2 con chị đang làm công nhân. Tham gia vào Quỹ, chị Dậu nhận được rất nhiều sự ủng hộ và khích lệ từ phía gia đình. Anh Trạnh chồng chị luôn là người hỗ trợ chị trong việc trả tiền tuần với nguồn thu nhập hàng ngày. Sau nhiều lần đầu tư nuôi lợn có hiệu quả, vòng vốn này chị đề nghị vay 500 USD về sửa chữa chuồng trại và mua thêm lợn, gà để chăn nuôi.

loans.use: buy chicken and pigs

loans.name: Thon

texts.en: At age 25, married with two children, Mrs. Thon C. lives with her husband in Kompung Cham province, Cambodia. To support her family, C. works on her plot of land raising pigs and growing vegetables, earning about US$ 6 each day. Her husband drives a motorcycle taxi, earning around $5 a day. He has recently decided that he would like to have a car as a taxi instead, which he thinks would enable him to earn more than in his current business. With this aim in mind, the couple has applied for a loan to purchase a used car to use to operate a taxi business.

loans.use: To purchase a used car to operate a taxi

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Rano

texts.ru:
Rano U. is 44 years old. She is married and has two children. She has a post-secondary education. Her husband is a salesman. Rano’s son repairs apartments and her daughter is going to school. Rano has been selling eggs for over 11 years. She started this business after the factory she worked in closed down. Rano began working with MLF “MicroInvest” in 2005. Back then, her assets were $150. After receiving her first loan and using it to grow and improve her business, Rano exchanged her point of sale for a better one, thereby increasing her sales turnover and improved her family’s standard of living. Her current assets are up to $300. In the future, she is planning to sell eggs wholesale.

Translated from Russian by Keith & Jamilya Leitich, Kiva Volunteers.

Усмонова Рано- 44лет. Замужем, мать двоих детей, образование среднее. Муж занимается торговлей, старший сын занимается ремонтом квартир, дочка учиться в школе. Рано занимается продажей яиц вот уже более 11лет. Начала она заниматься этой деятельностью, после того как заводы и фабрики были закрыты, и она осталась без работы. В МЗФ «Микроинвест» начала кредитоваться в 2005 году, тогда её активы составляли 150$. После получения займа и целевого использования она поменяла место своей деятельности на более лучшее, увеличила товарооборот и улучшила уровень жизни. Сейчас её активы возросли до 300$. В будущем планирует перейти и на оптовую продажу.

loans.use: Wholesale trade of eggs

loans.name: Than Chun

texts.en:
Mrs. Thun Chun L., 36, lives with her husband, 42, and her 2 children in the Kampong Cham district of Cambodia. She currently earns US$ 2 a day selling fish to people in her community, whilst her husband earns $5 a day operating a passenger cart drawn by a horse. The couple also grow some crops which they keep for their own consumption.

They would now like to increase their income by purchasing a pump. Mrs. Thun Chun L. feels this is a useful investment because she will use the pump herself so that she can irrigate her own land, but she will also make income renting it out to her neighbors.

loans.use: to purchase a pump to use in cultivating her own crops and to rent out to her community

payments.comment:
Congratulations to Than Chun Leng for repaying her loan early! And thank you for helping her to invest in her business and expand her income. We hope you will continue to support poor Cambodian entrepreneurs in the future.

Many thanks,
Jordyan Edmiston, Kiva Fellow
and the entire CREDIT MFI team

loans.name: Sou

texts.en: Mrs. Sou S. is 26 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She works selling vegetables at an open-air market, earning around US$ 7 a day in revenue, while her husband works as a horse-cart driver (a passenger cart pulled by a horse) and can typically generate about $4 per day. This loan is potentially intended to use for purchasing a horse and a cart for her husband to operate a business.

loans.use: To purchase a horse and a cart for her husband to operate a business

payments.comment: Congratulations to Sou Sokhoeun for repaying the Kiva loan early!

loans.name: Angeline

texts.en: Angeline S. is a widow and a mother of two children who are in school. Paying house rents and school fees for her children was a difficult task for her so she sought for capital from GHAPE in order to start cultivating crops so she can sell and raise money for these expenses. Presently, she has been able to invest and repay about five loans and now requests a new one of $1200 with which to invest in the buying and selling of drug supplements and crop cultivation. These drug supplements are now being taken by most elderly in this area. She plans to repay the loan in 24 months and the first installment of repayment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement.

loans.use: Purchase of drugs, clearing of farm, fertilizer

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Ester was born in 1959 and is a widow with six children. Her husband left her and her children with nothing to live on so she was forced to work hard so she could provide for her six children. All attempts to do business proved unfruitful as she lacked capital. Motivated by other members, she sought help from GHAPE so she could get a loan and invest in a business. She received and repaid six loans with which she raised money to pay school fees and buy food for her children. Given a loan of $1000, she plans to continue her business of pig fattening and yam and cassava cultivation so she can use the profits to continue educating her children. She plans to pay her loan in 24 months. The first installment repayment shall be on the fourth month from the date of disbursement.

loans.use: Purchase of food items and seeds and to hire labour

loans.name: Lum Julie

texts.en: Julie is married to a polygamist and is a mother of five kids. She has suffered from neglect from her husband who concentrates more on her maids and their children. Seeing the fact that the needs of her children could only be met by her, she decided to start a business and sought a loan from GHAPE with which she raised money and paid school fees for her children. Given a loan of $1200, she plans to buy motor bike to use as a taxi. Motor bike taxis are lucrative and common in this area due to the bad state of roads and because it is believed to be a faster means of transport. She plans to pay her loan in 24 months. The first installment repayment shall be on the fourth month from the date of disbursement

loans.use: Purchase of motor bike,

loans.name: Nanga Frida

texts.en: Nanga Frida is married and a mother of eight children. She has always been a hard working  woman with little or no fruits of her labour. This is because she could not lay her hands on a profitable business and even when she did, could not make profit because she lacked capital to invest. Because of this, her children were always suffered from not having school fees and hunger. With these challenges, she sought help from GHAPE in 1998. Since then she has been able to obtain loans with which she sold motor spare parts and raised enough money to pay an apprentice and school fees for her children. Given a loan of $1200, she plans to buy and  sell spare motor parts in the capital city of the country where more people own cars. Her son has built a house for the business so that a building will not have to be rented and she will use his experience to help manage it. She plans to pay her loan in 24 months. The first installment repayment shall be on the fourth month from the date of disbursement.

loans.use: Purchase of motor spare parts and construct a building for her business location

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a motor bike to use as a taxi

loans.name: Hortensia

texts.en:
Everything seemed to have ended when 44-year-old Hortensia lost her husband, who left her with four children. She realized she needed to start a business so she could raise money to take care of these children. After attending training in tailoring, she opened a workshop. However, she had difficulties because she did not have enough capital to invest.

She was then led to join GHAPE and received training in business skills. With a first loan of $100, she plans to sew and sell clothes so she can use the profit to pay school fees for her children. Over time, her community will also benefit, because she plans to train an apprentice.

Hortensia plans to repay her loan in 15 months. Her first installment repayment will be made on the date her loan is disbursed.

loans.use: Purchase cloth and thread, and pay rent

loans.name: Ndifor Sylvia

texts.en:
Because Sylvia was unemployed, she was unable to pay school fees for her children and buy them things they needed. She then sought help from GHAPE for capital to start selling raffia wine and koki beans in Mile Two, a commercial area in her town. Raffia wine, made from raffia plants, is drunk in the region and is especially appreciated on traditional occasions.

With a loan of $100, she plans to embark on this business and raise money to pay school fees for her children.

She plans to repay her loan in 15 months. Her first repayment will be made on the date her loan is disbursed.

loans.use: Purchase of raffia wine, four cups, and koki beans

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Born in 1972, Monica is a mother of two children who hates thinking about the time when she was abandoned in the hospital with her son, who later died. Lack and poverty have been the story of her life. By joining GHAPE, she believes things will change.

With a loan of $100, she plans to expand her water fufu business. She plans to sell water fufu and eru and use the profit to buy food and other needs for her children. Water fufu is grated fermented cassava, while eru is a wild vegetable. They are usually prepared together and are eaten mostly by southwesterners.

Monica plans to repay her loan in 15 months. Her first installment repayment will be made on the date her loan is disbursed.

loans.use: Purchase of  water fufu and eru

loans.name: Soliya

texts.ru:
Soliya B., 42 is married and has 3 children. She grew up in a working class family and has a high school education. In 2002, Soliya B. took her first MicroInvest loan of $140. Then, she sold pies and chebureki (a fried pita bread stuffed with meat). Gradually, having taught her children the trade, Soliya B. switched to cattle farming. Soliya and her husband are feeding cattle and then hand it over to butchers. Soliya’s son then uses the meat to prepare a variety of meat products such as pies, kebab, etc. (some of which you can see on the photo). Today, Soliya’s business assets grew up to $1000. In the future, Soliya B. plans to transition to wholesale delivery of fresh meat and build a farm. P.S. On the photo is her son.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Боймирзоева Солия – 42лет, замужем и имеет троих детей. Образование среднее, росла в семье рабочих. Начала кредитоваться в МЗФ «Микроинвест» с 2002-го года с активами на 140 $.Тогда она торговала пирожками и чебуреками. Постепенно научив, своих детей этой деятельности она, перешла кредитоваться в сфере животноводства, так как место расположенность ее дома очень идеальна для откорма скота. Она можно сказать создала контейнер в семейном бизнесе. Солия с мужем откармливают скот до полноты, сдают мясникам на убой, а сын использует мясо для изготовления мясных блюд, такие как пирожки, чебуреки и шашлыки, что мы можем видеть на фотографии на месте деятельности ее сына. Сейчас ее активы возросли до 1000$, а в будущем она планирует перейти на оптовую поставку свежего мяса и построить ферму.На фото ее сын.

loans.use: Transition to wholesale delivery of fresh meat

loans.name: Enjoh Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is a mother of seven whose dreams of educating her children were almost shattered when her unemployed husband could not provide their school fees. As a hardworking woman, she decided to start a business, and she obtained a loan from GHAPE with which she raised money to pay school fees for her children.

With a loan of $700, she plans to sell fattened pigs, sell cooked food, and do gardening. Planting of short-cycle crops to sell will give her a quick profit. Her pig business will provide manure for the community and for her garden. The profit will be used to increase her business and continue paying school fees for her children.

She plans to repay her loan in 18 months. The first installment repayment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement.

loans.use: Purchase foodstuff, piglets, seeds

loans.name: Fon Triphina

texts.en:
Born in 1964, Triphina is married and is the mother of seven children. She has suffered from the death of one daughter. She was unable to acquire capital to start a business that would help support her low-income husband. The discovery of GHAPE was a great relief for her. She obtained a first loan of $40 with which she sold foodstuffs, and she used the profit to pay part of the children’s school fees.

With a loan of $400, she plans to purchase groundnuts, koki beans, and other foodstuffs to sell so she can raise money to continue paying school fees and apprentice fees for her children.

She plans to repay her loan in 18 months. The first installment repayment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement.

loans.use: Purchase of groundnut, koki beans egusi, beans

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more merchandise for his stall.

loans.name: Nung Magdalene

texts.en:
Magdalene is a hardworking mother of eight and the wife of Isaac Tekoh. The consequences of a large family dawned on her and her husband when they discovered that the little income from his daily labor could not meet the family needs. This led her to start rearing pigs to sell. In the search for capital to invest, she contacted GHAPE and received a first loan of $40 and a second loan of $120.

With a loan of $700, she plans to continue rearing pigs but also fry and sell puff balls so she can raise money to pay school fees for her children.

She plans to repay her loan in 18 months. The first installment repayment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement.

loans.use: Purchase of flour, firewood, and piglets

loans.name: Pho

texts.en: Mrs. Pho M., 47, is married and lives in the Kampong Cham district of Cambodia. Currently, Pho M. herself does not work, but her husband, 50, runs a small stall charging vehicle batteries. Pho M. has applied for this loan so that she can buy speakers and musical instruments to rent out to the people in her area. She believes that there is demand for this as people like to play instruments on special occasions but do not want to buy them as they are not useful enough during the year.

loans.use: to buy speakers and musical instruments to rent to the people in her area

payments.comment: Congratulations to Pho Met for repaying the Kiva loan early!

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice was born in 1964 and is the mother of seven children. Her husband, Vincent, is unemployed, so he cannot provide basic needs for his family--particularly medications for his wife, who is suffering from health problems. This is why she joined GHAPE in 1999 and got a first loan of $30. Since then she has been able to manage and repay loan amounts up to $1200, with which she raised money to pay school fees for her children.

With a loan of $600, she plans to cultivate crops and fatten pigs, which she will sell. With the profit she makes, she can buy medication for herself and clothes for her family.

She plans to repay her loan in 24 months. The first installment repayment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement.

loans.use: Purchase of pigs and feed, fertilizer

loans.name: Mean

texts.en:
Mrs. Mean K. S. is 53 years old. She is a widow and lives with her four children. She has works very hard to support her entire family since her husband passed away many years ago.

Mrs. Mean K. S. works as a street-vendor selling different types of books, newspapers, and magazines. She plan to use this loan to expand her inventory by adding more items to meet growing customer demand.

loans.use: To expand her inventory by adding more products to meet her customers' needs

loans.name: Anye Felicia

texts.en:
The plight of the widows in this area is not something to ignore, especially when the relations of the late husband inherit all his property even when the widow is still alive. This is the story of Felicia, who was sent away from her late husband's house by her in-laws.

She therefore had to fend for herself and her family, and thanks to GHAPE she was able to start a business with the loan given her. With her first three loans amounting to $300, she was able to raise money to put back into her business.

With a loan of $400, she plan to sell cooked beans and puff balls, cultivate crops, and rear pigs. She will use the profit to educate her children.

Felicia plans to repay her loan in 18 months. The first installment repayment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement.

loans.use: Purchase of pigs and feed, seeds, clearing, tilling, beans, flour, firewood

loans.name: Abir

texts.en:
Abir A. B. is a 28-year-old woman living in Sharoun with her family. She learned embroidery on an instrument called 'A. nol' in 2005 and started selling her work one year later. She does also crochet which she learned from her mother at 13 years old. Nadine is a very talented and committed girl who sells her work to a workshop in Aley, and to neighbors in the surrounding villages. Nadine would like to borrow $300 to buy the required materiA. for her embroidery work. "My work is what allows me to be financially independent. My independence being the most important thing for me."

Abir is part of a group with other women from the same village. Her group name is 'A. Wouroud' which means roses. The group loan is a group of self-chosen women, living in vulnerable conditions, mostly in rurA. areas. The group lending is based on incrementA. increase of loan amount and group solidarity to guarantee repayment. The strength of the group loan is that is encourages the collaboration approach in the borrowing community. The group loan is a very powerful tool towards economic empowerment for women.

loans.use: To buy the necessary material for the embroidery work

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith was born in 1982 and is a mother of three. Her husband left her for another woman, so she had to single-handedly meet the needs of her children. This was very difficult, since she had no source of income. Motivated by other members, she joined GHAPE.

With a loan of $100, she plans to cultivate vegetables and sell small food items. The sale of short-cycle vegetables will give her a quick profit that she will use to pay school fees for her children.

Judith plans to repay the loan in 15 months. Her first installment repayment will be made on the date her loan is disbursed.

loans.use: Purchase of seeds, manure, clearing, food items.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more cabbages for sale.

loans.name: Susana Neh

texts.en:
Susana was born in 1942, is married, and is a mother of four children. She will never forget the death of one of her children, which left her emotionally disturbed for a long time.

She first joined GHAPE in 1999, and since then she has managed and invested loans amounting to $1200. This has raised her profits and enabled her to sponsor some of her children in school and vocational training.

With a loan of $1200, she plans to run a motor bike taxi business and cultivate yams. The motor bike will be ridden by her son, who is trained in that domain. She will use the profit from the business to continue sponsoring her children in vocational schools.

Susana plans to repay her loan in 24 months. The first installment repayment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement.

loans.use: Purchase of motor bike, documents, yams

loans.name: Fadia

texts.en:
Fadia A. S. is a married woman living in Sharoun with her family and her 4 children. Fadia used to sell cosmetic products from door to door. When this activity ended, she started knitting and doing crochet, skills she learned from her mother at age 15. She either sells her work at home or she passes her creations to a woman in charge of selling them. Fadia needs to buy the necessary materials and accessories to sustain and gradually develop her small business.

Fadia is part of a group with 5 other women from the same village. Her group's name is 'A. Eman' which means faith. The requested loan is for this group of self-chosen women, living in vulnerable conditions, mostly in rurA. areas. Group lending is based on incrementA. increase of loan amount and group solidarity to guarantee repayment. The strength of the group loan is that it encourages a collaborative approach in the borrowing community. The group loan is a very powerful tool towards the economic empowerment of women.

loans.use: To buy materials for her knitting and crochet work

loans.name: Isobelle

texts.en:
Having a polygamist as a husband can mean the wife needs to put in more effort to single-handedly take care of herself and her children, because the husband cannot provide sufficiently for all his wives and their children. That was the case of Isobelle, who had to solicit help from GHAPE to meet these demands.

Given a loan of $100, she plans to sell raffia and palm wine, wine highly consumed by the people in the region and made from raffia trees and palm trees. With the profit raised, she will pay school fees for her children and buy things they need.

Isobelle plans to repay the loan in 15 months. Her first installment repayment will be made on the first day her loan is disbursed.

loans.use: Purchase of raffia wine, palm wine

loans.name: Neba Christabel

texts.en:
Born in 1973, Christabel is married and is a mother of four children. She has suffered from challenges, such as family problems, ill health, and an attack by an armed robber who made away with some of her precious items.

Her husband has been sick for a while, so he could not work to make enough money to provide sufficiently for his family. His wife therefore decided to support him by starting a business so she could raise money to pay school fees for the children and buy food.

With a loan of $100, she plans to open a provision store near a residential area, to shorten the distance neighbors will have to go to buy goods. Through this business, she will raise money to pay school fees for her children.

Christabel will repay her loan in 15 months. Her first installment repayment will be made on the date her loan is disbursed.

loans.use: Purchase of groceries

loans.name: Najwa

texts.en:
On your way to the Chouf you can find in Sharoun village a small grocery shop. When you go in, you can smell the tasty odor of hot bread. If you talk to the person in front, you can see the smile of Najwa S.. If you order a 'mankoushé' (thyme baked on bread), you will definitely ask for another. Apparently Najwa has a secret recipe she got from her father who was a pastry cook.

"Once a customer told me he came especially to Sharoun for my 'manakish'," Najwa told us. Since her food is famous in the region, Najwa needs an oven for baking bread so as to be ready for all her customers' orders. That way she can also avoid health complications for herself. US$ 300, the amount Najwa is asking to borrow, is the price of the used oven she needs to have to improve her small business. Najwa is part of a group with 5 other women from the same village. Her group's name is 'Al Eman' which means faith. The group loan is for a self-chosen group of women, living in vulnerable conditions, mostly in rural areas. Group lending is based on incremental increase of the loan amount and group solidarity to guarantee repayment. The strength of the group loan is that is encourages the collaborative approach in the borrowing community. The group loan is a very powerful tool for economic empowerment of women.

loans.use: To buy an oven

loans.name: Kambit Sang

texts.en: Kambit S. lives in district 4 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is single, and he is supporting his family. He has a cosmetic shop in the main bazaar of Kabul in a good place. He has a small amount of merchandise in his shop, so he wants to buy more materials. He wants to take a group loan to increase his stock to make a good income for his family and a good future for himself. He is happy that he can solve his problem and he is thankful for AFSG.

loans.use: To increase his stock

loans.name: Nyoh Alice

texts.en:
Born in 1965, Alice is married and is a mother of five children. Her doom came when the local bank in which she and her husband kept their hard-earned money underwent liquidation.

Since then it has not been easy for her and her husband to meet the demands of their children. Motivated by other members, she became a GHAPE member and was trained in business skills.

With a loan of $80, Alice plans to produce and sell yogurt to primary school pupils. She will use the profit to provide school needs for her children.

She plans to repay the loan in 15 months. Her first installment repayment will be made on the date her loan is disbursed.

loans.use: Purchase of milk, sugar, and flavors, plus payment of electricity bill

loans.name: Bi Bi Takor

texts.en: Bi Bi Takor lives in district 4 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is a widow, and her husband died 7 years ago. She has 4 sons. They are married and are living out of her home. She is working just for herself. She is a tailor. She has a lot of experience in her job. She wants to expand her business, so she wants to take a group loan to buy new sewing machines to work hard and make a good future for herself. She is happy.

loans.use: To buy new sewing machines

loans.name: Junaedi

texts.id:
Junaedi is a hard working young man. He sells daily goods, such as soap, shampoo, balm, etc. around his neighborhood with his motorcycle. With $500 invested capital, he earns about $5 to $8.50 per day. Junaedi wants to expand his business by hiring a helper that would cost him about $300. He expects his business' productivity and profit to significantly grow with that extra help. Currently Junaedi lives with his friend who owns similar business. They share a room that costs $25/month to rent. Junaedi sends his excess earnings to his parents who still live in Java.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

/b> Junaedi adalah anak muda yang tekun dan ulet, saat ini Junaedi mempunyai usaha berjualan sandal serta kebutuhan Rumah tangga lainnya seperti sabun, shampo, minyak kayu putih dan sebagainya dengan cara berkeliling menggunakan sepeda motor. Dengan modal Rp.5.000.000 Junaedi memperoleh keuntungan Rp.50.000 s/d Rp. 75.000/hari. Junaedi berkeinginan untuk memgembangkan usahanya dengan menambah satu tenaga kerja dengan modal yang dibutuhkan Rp.3.000.000.- dengan harapan keuntungan akan lebih meningkat. Saat ini Junaedi tinggal dengan temannya dengan usaha yang sama, mereka tinggal di tempat kost dengan membayar sewa kamar Rp.250.000./bulan yang tentunya pembayarannya dibagi dua dengan temannya. Dari penghasilannya sebagai penjual kebutuhan sehari-hari Junaedi dapat mengirim sebagian uangnya kepada orang tuanya yang masih tinggal dijawa.

loans.use: Purchase goods to be sold

loans.name: Phan

texts.en:
Mrs. Phan H. is a 40-year-old mother of eight children and lives in Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She is a housewife and has to cook meals for her family, while her husband works as a motor-taxi driver. Two of her children work at construction and the rest attend school.

Mrs. Phan H. hopes to use this loan to purchase a motorcycle for her husband so that he won’t spend so much on public transportation when he goes to work every day. (This is a picture of her husband because Mrs. Phan H. was unavailable when the photo was taken.)

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her husband to ride to work

loans.name: Savri

texts.ru:
Savri P. has been in the trade business for 13 years. She is married with 3 children and has a community college diploma. She started out by selling children’s clothing, with assets worth about $50. Gradually she moved on to selling men’s clothing. After getting her first loan, Savri increased the variety of her inventory (she added men’s sportswear), secured a better selling location and had her son also join the business to help out. Today her assets are worth twice what they were initially. Savri plans to increase her sales using the new loan.

Translated from Russian by Olga Espira, Kiva Volunteer.

Парпиева Саври вот уже 13лет занимается торговлей. Замужем, имеет троих детей, образование среднее специальное. Начала свою деятельность с продажи детской одежды, тогда её активы составляли 50$. Постепенно она перешла на продажу мужской одежды. После получения займа она увеличила ассортимент товара (добавила мужскую спортивную одежду), приобрела новое более лучшее место для торговли, также сын начал помогать своей матери в торговле. Сейчас её активы увеличились в два раза больше. В дальнейшем планирует увеличить товарооборот

loans.use: to increase sales/turnover

loans.name: Roni

texts.id:
Currently Roni works for a lamp cover factory owned by his sibling that pays him $70-$100 per month. Seeing the growth and profitability of his sibling's business, he wants to challenge himself by starting his own business with loan from DINARI and some additional funding help from his brother. With his skills and 5 year experience from working for his sibling, Roni is well qualified to start similar business, except that he still needs to secure funding. With $100 per month capital to buy raw materials like bamboo, Roni expects to earn $15 per week. Roni plans to use some of those profit to pay his $175 per year lease for his facilities.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

Roni saat ini bekerja disalah satu usaha membuat kap lampu yang dimiliki oleh saudaranya, dengan penghasilan Rp.700.000 - Rp.1.000.000.- perbulan. Melihat perkembangan usaha tersebut cukup mendukung akhirnya Roni ditantang untuk membuka usaha sendiri dengan bantuan modal dari saudaranya dan pinjaman dari DINARI. Dengan pengalaman dan kemampuannya selama 5 tahun bekerja dengan saudaranya Roni tidak mengalami kesulitan untuk membuka usaha yang sama kecuali dari segi permodalan. Dengan modal Rp.1.000.000.-perbulan yang digunakan untuk membeli bahan-bahan anyaman dari bambu dan sapu lidi, Roni dapat meraup keuntungan Rp.150.000 /minggu.dengan keuntungan tersebut Roni harus menyisihkan sebagian keuntungannya untuk membayar tempat yang disewanya dengan harga sewa Rp.1.750.000./tahun.

loans.use: Purchase raw materials for his business

loans.name: Ayubdjon

texts.ru:
Ayubdjon H. is 27 yrs old, married and has a college diploma. He has been selling food since childhood because his father was not able to support the family due to frequent illnesses. He used to work/sell together with his sister, working on busy city streets with no fixed location. This resulted in frequent warnings and harassment from local authorities concerned about public order in central city streets. Such disruptions greatly affected his earnings, down to the basic ability to earn enough to feed himself and his family.

After learning about the collateral-free credit program at MLF MicroInvest he became a member in 2002 and obtained a loan for $100. Gradually he increased the variety of his offerings and most importantly was able to obtain a permanent trading stall at the central city market. All this showed his dedication to the MicroInvest program and his discipline. In the future, he plans to use the loans to move into wholesale trade.

Translated from Russian by Olga Espira, Kiva volunteer.

Хакимов Аюбджон – 27 лет ,женат образование среднее. С детства занимается торговлей продуктами питания, поскольку его отец не в силах обеспечить семью материально из-за частой болезни. Торговал со своей сестрой в многолюдных улицах без постоянного место деятельности и постоянных натисков местных органов по порядке центральных улиц, что сильно влияло зарабатывать хотя бы на хлеб. Узнав о программе без залогового кредитования для микро-предпринимателей в МЗФ «Микроинвест» Аюбджон без сомнения стал кредитоваться с 2002-го года с активами на 100$. Постепенно он увеличил свой ассортимент товара, добавил продукты питания и кроме всего приобрел постоянную точку деятельности в центральном рынке города, что говорит о его дисциплинированности перед программой. В будущем планирует перейти на оптовую продажу.

loans.use: To move into wholesale trade

loans.name: Log Kor

texts.en: Log Kor lives in district 4 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married and has 3 children. She knits. She works in her home and sells her crafts in the bazaar. She loves to help her husband with the family expenses so she wants to take a group loan to buy extra materials for her business. She hopes to have lots of clients to improve her business and make a better future for her family. She is happy.

loans.use: To buy extra materials

loans.name: Suzanne

texts.en:
"I began doing crochet at the age of 25. My mother taught me the skill," says Suzanne G., who started selling her work in 2002 which helped her gain financial independence and build her self-confidence. She is a 32-year-old mother (of 3 children) proud to be a productive, professionally active woman. She lives with her family in a village in Mount Lebanon called El Mecherfé.

When a girl in the surrounding villages is a bride to be, she comes to Suzanne to purchase crochet sets for her new home. Suzanne now plans to buy crochet thread for US$ 300, enough to produce 30 pieces of crochet which equals around 6 home furniture sets.

Suzanne is part of a group with 3 other women from the same village. Her group name is "Al Nour" which means the light. This is a group of self-chosen women, living in vulnerable conditions, mostly in rural areas. Group lending is based on incremental increase of loan amount and group solidarity to guarantee repayment. The strength of the group loan is that it encourages the collaborative approach in the borrowing community. The group loan is a very powerful tool towards the economic empowerment of women.

loans.use: To buy needed materials for her crochet work

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her cereal business.

loans.name: Sarraf

texts.en:
Mr. Sarraf s is a low-income vulnerable person. He is 39, married with two children, and lives in the village of Saatli town in the south-central flat area of Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region.

Sarraf has his own bread shop. His bread is in great demand among customers because it is very tasty. His baker (shown in the picture) says that sometimes when breads are sold out, it is hard to see the eyes of the empty-handed customers. Sarraf decided to apply for a $1000 loan from the Normicro Saatli branch. When he receives the loan, he can buy more meal to make his monthly income higher. With the extra income, he will repay back the loan he received and after that save money to buy a microwave oven for the bakery.

loans.use: To buy raw materials

loans.name: Dilafruz

texts.ru:
Dilafruz is relatively new to business. She sells clothing, footwear, and schoolbags for children. Recently, Dilafruz turned 20. Sales profits contribute to her family’s budget, as Dilafruz lives with her parents. Dilafruz joined MicroInvest in April and has already earned a reputation of exemplary borrower. Her new loan, Dilafruz plans to use to purchase fall collection of children’s clothing.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Дилафруз занимается бизнесом сравнительно недавно. Она продает детские одежду и обувь. Также у нее в ассортименте школьные сумки. Недавно Дилафруз исполнилось 20 лет. Доходы от занятия торговлей дополняют семейный бюджет семьи Дилафруз, так как она живет с родителями. В Микроинвест она кредитуется с апреля месяца, и уже показала себя как образцовая клиентка. Новый займ она собирается потратить на приобретение осеннего ассортимента детской одежды.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Balirsing

texts.en: Balirsing lives in district 4 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married and has 4 children. He is an internally displaced person from India. He lost one of his feet during the war in Afghanistan. He is selling and making medicine and helping his family. His wife was supporting the family before he started this business three years ago. He wants to expand his business, so he wants to take a group loan to increase his stock to support his family and increase their living standard.

loans.use: To increase his stock

loans.name: Yol

texts.en:
Mrs. Yol O., 60, lives in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. To support her family, she works selling a variety of grocery products to the people in her community, earning US$ 3 a day, whilst her husband works as a teacher and generally makes around $1 per day. One of their children works on a farm plowing and growing crops; another one is a worker, and the other two are students.

Mrs. Yol O. is humbly requesting a loan to purchase a hand tractor, which can be used to assist them in plowing and working on their farmland . She plans to use the remainder of the money to increase her inventory by adding more products to better meet her customers’ needs.

loans.use: To purchase a hand tractor, which can be used for plowing and working on their farmland

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Abulfas

texts.en:
Mr. Abulfas is a low-income vulnerable person. He is 50, married with two children, and lives in the village of Saatli town in the south-central flat area of Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region.

Abulfas and his son (he is shown in the picture) run the family business together. Abulfas sells beef in the Saatli town, while his son grazes cattle. Their volume of beef sold is growing. To supply the demand of his customers, Abulfas decided to apply for a $1000 loan from the Normicro Saatli branch. In the Caucasus region, the price of a cow is up to $400. If Abulfas receives the loan, he will add two cows more to his herd. It will allow him to provide the necessities of life for the family.

loans.use: To buy cows

loans.name: Ngwa

texts.en:
M. Ngwa is 38 years old, is married, and is a father of four children who are all in school. With a heavy burden of having to pay the children’s school fees, caring for his sick child, and providing basic needs for his family, he asked for help from GHAPE in 2005. He was given a loan of $40, with which he raised poultry. He used the profit to pay his children’s school fees.

With a loan of $250, M. plans to rear goats and pigs, and continue with his poultry business. He will use the profit to educate his children and provide basic needs for his family. He will also sell piglets to other farmers in his community.

He plans to repay the loan in 15 months. His first installment repayment will made on the date his loan is disbursed.

loans.use: Purchase animal feed, chicken, goats, piglets

loans.name: Judith

texts.en: Judith O. sells provisions. She is 36 years old. She is a married mother of 6 children and has been in LAPO as a member for 3 years. She hopes to expand her business with the loan of $475. She has been in business since 1982.

loans.use: To buy more provisions for sale

loans.name: Omina

texts.ru:
Omina J. has been in business selling eggs for 8 years. She is married and has four children. She has a post-secondary education. Her husband is a salesman. Her eldest daughter is married and the rest of the children are going to school. Omina started her business with $30. Omina received her first loan of $70 from MLF “MicroInvest” in 2004. She slowly increased sales turnover and attracted many clients which helped her to improve her standard of living. She has doubled her assets and she is planning to start selling eggs wholesale with the new loan.

Translated from Russian by Keith & Jamilya Leitich, Kiva Volunteers.

Чураева Омина занимается продажей яиц вот уже 8лет. Замужем, имеет четверых детей, образование среднее. Муж занимается торговлей, старшая дочь замужем остальные дети учатся в школе. Начала она заниматься этой деятельностью с 30$. В МЗФ «Микроинвест» первый займ в размере 70$ получила в 2004году. Постепенно она увеличила товарооборот, приобрела много клиентов, и улучшила уровень жизни. Сейчас её активы возросли в два раза больше, и в будущем она планирует перейти на оптовую продажу.

loans.use: Wholesale trade of eggs

loans.name: Vahobjon

texts.ru:
Vahobjon is a very modern energetic man. He is 38, married, and has 4 underage children. The entire family is engaged in Vahobjon’s business. Vahobjon has a retail spot on Isfarinskiy bus terminal, where he and his wife, with the help of their children, sell small goods including fried sunflower seeds, chewing gum, cigarettes, etc. In addition, Vahobjon rented the bus terminal’s public bathroom, which he now maintains, and earns an income by charging an entrance fee. Vahobjon personally travels to the regional center to purchase his goods. He received the first MicroInvest loan a year ago. Having received a few loans, Vahobjon significantly expanded his business. His next loan, Vahobjon plans to use to purchase sunflower seeds, as the season of low prices is approaching.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Вахобчон очень современный и энергичный мужчина. Ему 38 лет, он женат и у него 4 несовершенолетних детей. Вся его семья занимается бизнесом и всем этим он управляет. На Исфаринском автовокзале у него есть торговое место, где он и его жена торгуют мелкими товарами – жаренными семечками подсолнуха, жевательной резинкой, сигаретами и т.п. здесь им помогают их дети. Также Вахобчон взял в аренде общественный туалет при автовокзале, где он следит за порядком и получает от этого доход в виде оплаты за вход. Вахобчон также сам ездит за товаром в областной центр. Кредитоваться в Микроинвест он стал год назад. Получив несколько займов он значительно расширил свой бизнес. Очередной займ Вахобчон хочет получить на закуп семечек подсолнуха, так как скоро наступает сезон снижения цен на них.

loans.use: To purchase sunflower seeds

loans.name: Azamjon

texts.ru:
Azamjon A., 23 is married and has a high school education. He sells “a thousand little things” including hair pins, thread spools, wallets, etc. Azamjon A. learned the trade by helping his brother to sell. Then, he opened his own business. In 2005, he received his first loan of $100. Gradually increasing the assortment of goods, Azamjon A. bought a retail spot. He began to sell wholesale as well as retail. Now, his business assets grew up to $1300. Azamjon A. plans to purchase another retail spot.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Абдуллоев Аъзамчон 23лет, женат, образование среднее. Аъзамчон занимается реализацией тысяча мелочей (заколки для волос, нитки, кошельки и т.д.). Помогая своему брату в торговле, он набрал опыт в этой деятельности и открыл свой бизнес. В 2005году он получил первый займ в размере 100$. Постепенно он увеличил ассортимент товара и приобрел своё место для торговли, стал реализовать товар оптом и в розницу. Сейчас его активы возросли до 1300$, и в будущем он планирует открыть еще одну торговую точку.

loans.use: To open another retail spot

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Mrs. Helen O. is a member of the Nosakhore LAPO union in the Benin branch. Helen is 38 years old and married with a child. She has been with LAPO for 6 years and has been in this business since 2000. She is seeking a $475 loan to buy bags of rice, groundnut oil and other foodstuffs for sale.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for sale

loans.name: Farida

texts.ru:
Farida N. is divorced with three children. Though she has a higher education and works as an instructor at a secondary school, she also has been selling eggs for over 14 years. Since she is raising her children alone, it has not been an easy life for her. She started her business in order to improve her family’s standard of living and pay for her children’s education. She received her first loan of $70 in 2004. After receiving several loans and using them successfully, she increased sales turnover, started selling eggs to small cafes and food courts. In the future, she is planning to acquire another point of sale. The picture is of her sister.

Translated from Russian by Keith & Jamilya Leitich, Kiva Volunteers.

Норматова Фарида разведенная, мать троих детей. Хотя у нее образование высшее и она работает учительницей в средней школе, она занимается также торговлей яиц вот уже 14лет. Из-за нелегкой жизни, поскольку она одна содержала семью Фарида начала заниматься этой деятельностью, чтобы улучшить уровень жизни и дать образование своим детям. Первый займ в размере 70$, она получила в 2004году. После неоднократного получения займа и целевого использования она расширила место своей деятельности, увеличила товар, стал раздавать товар в маленькие торговые точки и кафе. В будущем планирует приобрести еще одну торговую точку товар. На фото её сестра.

loans.use: To open another point of sale

loans.name: Farhod

texts.en:
K. Farhod is one of the active clients of MicroInvest. His business is trade of soft drinks, and he has his own shop in the bus station "Abreshim." He has been engaged in this business since 2004.

From the beginning, he sold a limited number of soft drinks. With loans from MicroInvest, he increased his working capital and expanded his assortment by including alcoholic drinks. Today his turnover is fast. He concluded an agreement with five-distributor firm that produces soft and alcoholic drinks for a long partnership. They are responsible for supplying their goods for sale in his shop. He says that his business is very profitable, and he has big plans for developing his business. In the near future, he wants to save enough money to open a bar. Currently he plans to increase the number of his drinks and he is requesting $1000 for this purpose.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Dora

texts.en: "I have run a timber business for 3 years. This business is my family's source of income. I hope to receive a loan of $800 so that I can buy timber for sale," says Mrs. Dora N., who is married and a mother of 6 children. She is 63 years old. She has been with LAPO for 6 years as a leader of her union. She lives in Benin City and she enjoys her business.

loans.use: To buy more timber

loans.name: Nuriniso

texts.ru:
Nuriniso S. is a widowed mother of 4 children. She has a high school education. Nuriniso has been selling clothing for men for 15 years. She began her business by selling clothing for children. Then, she did not have a permanent trading spot. Unable to support her family, in 2002, Nuriniso S. took a MicroInvest loan of $70 to expand the assortment of goods. Since then, she took multiple MicroInvest loans, which Nuriniso used to increase the assortment of goods and purchase a trading spot in a store. Now, she sells more and purchases the goods more frequently. In the future, Nuriniso S. plans to purchase another trading spot.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Собирова Нуринисо вдова, мать четверых детей, образование среднее. Занимается торговлей мужской одежды вот уже 15лет. Начала она свою деятельность с продажи детской одежды, тогда она не имела постоянную месту для торговли. Поскольку ей стало трудно в содержании семьи она решила получить займ и расширить ассортимент товара. В 2002году она получила первый займ в размере 70$. После неоднократного получения кредита она целенаправленно использовала займ и тем самым увеличила товарооборот, приобрела торговую точку в магазине, часто стала ездить за товаром. В будущем планирует приобрести еще одну торговую точку.

loans.use: To open a new trading spot

loans.name: Mamlakat

texts.ru:
Mamlakat B., 37 is married and has 3 children. She has high school education. Mamlakat has been selling shoes for men for 5 years. According to her, before Mamlakat joined MicroInvest, she sold small quantities of shoes at various parts of town having no permanent place of business. Today, her business assets grew up to $800. By carefully investing the loaned funds, Mamlakat was able to establish a permanent place for her business at one of the central regional markets. Her husband helps Mamlakat in business. In the future, Mamlakat plans to purchase her goods from wholesalers directly instead of waiting for the local suppliers to deliver them. She also wants to increase the assortment of shoes in her store.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Бобочонова Мамлакат- 37 лет, замужем, мать 3-их детей. Образование среднее. Вот уже 5 лет занимается продажей мужской обуви. По ее словам до того, как стала клиентом МЗФ «Микроинвест» ,продавала обувь в малом ассортименте в разных частях города без определенного место деятельности. Муж помогает жене в торговле. Сейчас ее активы достигают 800$ ,что говорит о том, что у нее увеличился товарооборот и что она очень целенаправленно использует каждые шаги кредитования. В настоящее время она продолжает эту деятельность в определенной точке в одном из центральных рынков области. В будущем она планирует ездить за товаром сама не ожидая поступления от местных поставщиков и увеличить ассортимент товара.

loans.use: To increase assortment of goods

loans.name: Ayubjon

texts.ru:
Ayubjon M. is 19, single and has a high school education. He sells men's clothing. Despite being only 19, Ayubjon has extensive experience in sales. He has chosen to work and help out his family financially instead of pursuing his education. The reason why he is looking for a loan is because he purchases goods from suppliers for cash. He does not have enough cash to be able to increase turnover, which will allow him to purchase goods cheaper. This is exactly why he came up with the idea of borowing money through MicroInvest. Currently his assets amount to $1500 and he has a permanent sales point. In the future he is planing to open a store and use the left over money to go to college. His father is on the picture.

Translated from Russian by Yevgeniya Mazur, Kiva volunteer

Миркалонов Аюбчон – 19 лет, холост, образование среднее. Торгует мужской одеждой. Не смотря на свои 19 лет Аюбчон имеет большой опыт в этой деятельности, так как оставив учебу ,для поддержания уровни жизни семьи, занимается бизнесом, что в наше время является более доходным . Причиной толкнувшим клиента брать займ стало приобретение товара за наличние у поставщиков. Дело в том, что чтобы увеличить товарооборот у него не хватало достаточно средств купить товар подешевле за наличние. И в такое трудное время для него, пришла мысль о кредитовании в МЗФ «Микроинвест» .Сейчас его активы достигают 1500$ и у него постоянное место деятельности. В будущем хочет открыть магазин и из оставшихся доходов учится в университете. На фото его отец.

loans.use: to open a shop and study in University

loans.name: Abie

texts.en: Mrs. Abie O. is the union secretary of Nosakhare in the Oka branch. She is 37 years old, married, and the mother of five children. She is a fashion designer and sells fabrics in her shop. She has been in this business since 1997, and she is eager to get the loan of $800 for purchase of clothes and tailoring material for business growth. She lives in Benin City, in Edo State in Nigeria.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine & fabrics

loans.name: Sanovar

texts.ru:
Sanovar A., 39 is married and has 4 children. She has high school education. Sanovar has been selling clothing for women for 11 years. She thought of obtaining a MicroInvest loan, when she was looking for a source of credit that did not require collateral and could be easily used for business expansion. When Sanovar joined MicroInvest, she had $1000 in business assets. Sanovar A. personally travels to purchase her goods from wholesalers. She pays cash to obtain better prices. Today, Sanovar A. has a dedicated selling spot in a large store. In the future, she wants to rent an entire store and expand the assortment of fashionable clothing for men.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Абдуллоева Сановар – замужем, мать 4-их детей .Ей 39 лет, образование у нее среднее. Занимается торговлей женской одежды в течении 11 лет. Мысли о кредитовании пришли ей тогда, когда она хотела найти источник доступных средств,что могло позволить ей брать кредит без залога и без лишних трудностей для увеличения товарооборота. Таким образом,она стала клиентом МЗФ «Микроинвест» с активами на 1000$. Теперь Сановар ездит за товаром сама, целенаправленно используя займ покупает товар за наличные и кроме того она имеет определенное место в одном отделе большого магазина. В будущем она хочет взять в аренду магазин только для себя, и добавить в свой ассортимент модные мужские одежды.

loans.use: To rent a store and expand assortment of clothes for men

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria A. is 30 years old. She is a married mother of 5 children. She has a small firewood business in her house, where people in the neighborhood come to buy. She has been with LAPO for 4 years and has 10 years of experience in her business. She lives in Benin City and needs the loan of $400 to buy more firewood for sale.

loans.use: To buy firewood

loans.name: Mahfiratchon

texts.ru:
Mahfiratchon G. is 53. She is married and has 3 children. She has a high school education. She lives together with her retired husband. Her children have families of their own and live separately from the parents. She lost her job after the disintegration of the USSR. Her husband was laid off as well. In order to not be financially dependent on her children and maintain her lifestyle she began working in sales. Back in 2003 her assets amounted to $150. She was selling children's clothing. Thanks to the loan and her commitment to the MicroInvest program she was able to increase her assets to $700. She was able to secure a permanent sales point and expanded her inventory to include children's shoes. In the future she is planing to procureanother sales point and increase turnover.

Translated from Russian by Jane Mazur, Kiva volunteer

Гиязова Махфиратчон – 53 лет, мать 3-их детей. Замужем, образование среднее специальное. Муж -пенсионер ,живут они вместе. У детей свои семьи и живут они отдельно от родителей. После развала советского союза Махфиратчон осталась без работы, а ее муж был в числе сокращенных рабочих. Чтобы быть не в тягость детям она начала заниматься торговлей с 2003-го года с активами на 150$, для поддержания уровни жизни. Она занималась торговлей детской одежды. После непрерывного кредитования, целенаправленностью перед программой МЗФ и своею порядочностью, она увеличила свои активы до 700$. Тем самым она приобрела постоянное место деятельности и добавила в свой ассортимент детскую обувь. В будущем планирует открыть еще одну точку торговли и увеличить товарооборот.

loans.use: to open another sales point and increase inventory selection

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: "LAPO has poor people in their hearts due to the way they treat us well," says Stella J.. She joined LAPO in 2005, after a friend of her told her about the organization. She is a married woman with 3 children. She has a boutique where she sells clothes and has been in the business since 2006. She needs the loan of $175 to buy more fabrics for sale.

loans.use: To buy more fabrics for sale

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: "I spend my profit to care for my children, so that I can meet my family needs and no longer have to worry about what my children will eat at the beginning of a new day," says Mrs. O.. She is a hairdresser from Edo State, and also sells provisions and drinks. She needs the loan of $250 to increase her business, for such expenses as buying more hair cream, hair weaves, drinks and provisions. She is 41 years old and married with 6 children. She has been in this business since 1997.

loans.use: To buy more weaves, hair creams and drinks for sale

loans.name: Bobojon

texts.en:
Bobojon is a young businessman. His business is trading melons and watermelons. His business place is located in Ckalovsk, Khujand. His trade place is situated near the road, and it is very profitable place. It is a very convenient place for customers, as they have the opportunity to buy melons and watermelons without going out of their way.

Bobojon says that as the weather was very hot in summer, he sold 40 or 60 melons (watermelons) every 2-3 days. One batch of his product consists of 200-500 melons and watermelons. He buys his product from suppliers from Mastchoh, district of Khujand, Tajikistan. For today, his turnover is fast; for the future, he plans to increase his volume of melons and watermelons. For this purpose he is requesting $1200 which he will pay back over 12 months.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Doris

texts.en: Mrs. A. 48 years old and married with five children. She lives in Egor quarters in Benin City. She sells provisions and foodstuffs; she wishes to buy more provision and foodstuffs for sale with the loan of $325. She has been in this business since 1989 and has been with LAPO for 9 years.

loans.use: To buy more provisions & foodstuffs for sale

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Mrs. A. has been a leader of her union for 3 years. She is 39 years old and married with 4 children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, and deals in fabrics. She has been in this business since 2000 and hopes to buy more stock and expand her business with the loan of $250.

loans.use: To buy more fabrics for sale

loans.name: Edith

texts.en: I have been running this business for the past 11 years. Through this business my family welfare and needs are being taken care of. Also I have been a LAPO member for 4 years and they have not failed me. I hope to increase my business with this $400, which will be used for the purchase of kerosene. I live in Benin City, Edo State. I am 40 years old and a married mother of 10 children.

loans.use: To buy more kerosene for sale

loans.name: Queen

texts.en: Queen A. is a 33-year-old woman, married with 2 children. She deals provisions, drinks, frozen chicken and foodstuffs in Benin City, in the Edo State of Nigeria. She is seeking a $250 loan for expansion of her business and for purchase of provisions, drinks and frozen chicken. She has been in LAPO for 2 years and has 4 years of experience in her business.

loans.use: To buy more provisions, drinks & frozen chicken for sale

loans.name: Osamede

texts.en: Osamede A. is 30 years old and a dynamic client of LAPO who specializes in sales of provisions, drinks and foodstuffs for people in her community. She hopes to improve her business with the loan of $250 by buying more stock. She a is married woman with 5 children and has been in this business since 1997.

loans.use: To buy more provisions, drinks & foodstuffs for sale

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en: Fatuma is a 22-year-old mother of one child and a resident of the Buguruni area. She owns a shop in Kariokoo, Dar es Salaam’s busiest trading area, and she sells new clothes. She has been in business for the past two years and orders her items from Hong Kong. She mainly sells little children’s clothing and ladies' outfits.  She is in need of US$400 to help her expand her business.

loans.use: Expand her business
